deliberation: Checked for figurative use of הַדָּבָר ('the word'), the writing-on-scroll language, and the chronological formula. All are standard prophetic and narrative formulae functioning literally (a spoken divine message, physically written on a scroll, dated to a specific regnal year). No clear metaphor, personification, idiom, hyperbole, or metonymy beyond normal lexical usage.

Examined the messenger formula כֹּה־אָמַר יְהוָה אֱלֹהֵי יִשְׂרָאֵל ('thus said YHWH, the God of Israel') and the phrase עָלֶיךָ בָּרוּךְ ('concerning you, Baruch'). These are standard formulae identifying the speaker and addressee; no transferred imagery, no anthropomorphism beyond normal theistic language, and no idiomatic expressions in need of figurative classification.

This lament includes several non-literal expressions: the cry 'אוי־נא לי' is a conventional idiom of lament; 'יָסַף יְהוָה יָגוֹן עַל־מַכְאֹבִי' portrays grief as something quantitatively 'added' to pain; and 'מְנוּחָה לֹא מָצָאתִי' pictures rest as an object one searches for and finds. These are distinct figurative/idiomatic expressions within the same verse.

lamentative posture in prophetic discourse
instances.explanation: The phrase “אוי־נא לי / Woe is me” is a fixed lament idiom that intensifies and dramatizes Baruch’s distress, going beyond a bare statement of ‘I am sad’ and functioning as a hyperbolic cry of calamity.

instances.explanation: Grief (an intangible emotion) is depicted as something God can ‘add’ on top of pain as if they were measurable, stackable burdens. This conceptualizes suffering as an accumulating load, a metaphorical and partly idiomatic way to describe intensified affliction.

deliberation: Verse 4 clearly shifts into imagery: God speaks of ‘what I have built’ and ‘what I have planted’ which He will now ‘tear down’ and ‘uproot’. These are standard prophetic metaphors for God’s establishment and subsequent dismantling of a nation/people. In addition, the phrase ‘כׇּל־הָאָרֶץ’ functions metonymically/synecdochically for the whole national entity (land with its people and structures), not merely the soil.

architectural structure being torn down

ground: both a built structure and a nation’s institutions are created, ordered entities that can later be dismantled

posture: God’s assertion of sovereign right to dismantle what He has established

prophetic pronouncement of drastic reversal
instances.explanation: God did not literally build Judah as a physical house; rather, Judah’s national existence is metaphorically portrayed as a building God constructed and will now demolish. It is a stock prophetic metaphor for divine founding and overthrow of a kingdom.

instances.explanation: Here Judah (and/or the broader people under judgment) is pictured as something God has ‘planted,’ now to be ‘uprooted’. The agricultural metaphor depicts the end of a divinely nurtured existence in the land.

instances.explanation: ‘The whole land’ functions metonymically (and as a kind of synecdoche) for the entire national community—land plus people and structures. It is not limited to soil, but stands for the totality of the covenant territory and its occupants.

deliberation: The closing verse contains a key metonymic/synecdochic expression, ‘עַל־כׇּל־בָּשָׂר’ (‘upon all flesh’), where ‘flesh’ stands for mortal human beings, and a vivid metaphor/idiom, ‘אֶת־נַפְשְׁךָ לְשָׁלָל’ (‘your life as spoil/booty’), picturing Baruch’s survival as plunder taken from a battlefield. These are two distinct figurative devices.

human domain
vehicle: ‘all flesh’ as a description of embodied, living beings
flesh as a term for creaturely, mortal life
biological/physical domain
ground: flesh is the visible, vulnerable aspect of living creatures, so it can stand for ‘mortals’ as such
association of ‘flesh’ with frailty and creatureliness
use of a bodily characteristic to denote the whole person or class of persons
posture: God’s announcement of comprehensive judgment on all mortals in view
stance emphasizing universality and vulnerability of those judged
prophetic rhetoric highlighting the scope and seriousness of disaster
instances.explanation: The expression ‘all flesh’ does not focus on literal meat but uses ‘flesh’ as a metonym/synecdoche for mortal human beings. It highlights human frailty and the universality of those included in the threatened disaster.

instances.english_text: but I will at least grant you your life as booty/spoil

his ongoing existence and safety
individual human survival
vehicle: war booty (spoil) that someone manages to take from a battlefield or conquered place
valuable plunder spared from destruction
military/warfare domain of plundering
ground: both spared plunder and Baruch’s survival are ‘rescued’ from a situation of widespread loss and destruction
perception of life as a precious gain taken from the jaws of disaster
contrast between what is lost and the small portion salvaged
posture: God’s promise that, though judgment is coming, Baruch’s survival will be his only ‘gain’
stance that redefines life itself as the sole spoils of war granted by divine mercy

instances.explanation: The idiom ‘to give one’s life as spoil’ is a metaphor from warfare: Baruch’s continued life is likened to plunder snatched from a battlefield. It pictures survival as the only ‘booty’ salvaged from the devastation God is bringing.
